Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of Instrumentation in Support of Laboratory Research and Training in Botany and Conservation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

Funds from the Major Research Instrumentation-Recovery and Reinvestment (MRI-R2) program were used to support the acquisition of a tabletop scanning electron microscope and associated equipment at the Missouri Botanical Gardens (MBG). An automated microscopy system was also acquired to facilitate the digitization of specimen slides. The instrumentation provides expanded research opportunities for a wide range of MBG curators, students, and visitors in research areas such as plant taxonomy, ecology, evolution, biogeography, pollen biology, ethnobotany, GIS and conservation. Research at MBG promotes the study and conservation of plants all over the world, from biodiversity tropical hotspots to native plants and habitats in Missouri, involving people from diverse cultures, occupations, age groups and ethnicity. Scientific study of plants provides the knowledge needed for rational management and conservation of plant resources. The acquired instrumentation expands the MBG laboratory capacity and allows botanists and students to extend their investigations, discovery, and propagation of knowledge. Use of the instruments is promoted through demonstrations in the garden's K-12 education programs, teacher training, special workshops and undergraduate research programs. The knowledge gained from the use of this instrumentation is widely disseminated through popular and technical publications, seminars, meetings, and building tours.

Project Outcomes Report

MRI-R2: Acquisition of Instrumentation in Support of Laboratory Research and Training in Botany and Conservation.

Award Number: 0958873

PI: David Bogler, Missouri Botanical Garden

 

            An award of $97,033 was made to the Missouri Botanical Garden (MBG) to purchase a tabletop JEOL 5000 Neoscope Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) and associated accessory equipment (Denton Desktop V sputter coater, EMS K850 critical point dryer). The SEM was used by curatorial staff, graduate students, and visitors to observe and photograph minute structures and surfaces of plant flowers, leaves, fruits, seeds, and pollen. The images and information from them were used in published papers, posters for scientific meetings, master's theses, PhD dissertations, websites, and taxonomic revisions of plant species. In the last three years we have trained over 70 staff members, students, and visitors to use the SEM equipment. The SEM greatly enhances MBG research capacity and education programs.

 

            The most frequent users were graduate students working on theses and dissertations. MBG belongs to a consortium of local universities (Washington University, University of Missouri at St. Louis, and St. Louis University) in which graduate students get degrees from the university while using the MBG herbarium, laboratory facilities, and expertise. Representative graduate student projects included:

Saul Hoyos, University of Missouri at St. Louis, "Floral symmetry in Fusispermum and Rinnorea (Violaceae)." Leaf epidermal characters were very useful in placing the phylogenetic position of these tropical woody relative of the temperate herbaceous violets.

Alejandra Domic, St. Louis University, "Ecology of Polylepis (Rosaceae): Fungal infection of the flowers of Polylepis tomentella." The fungus interferes and  interacts with pollination mechanisms.

BrieAnna Langlie, Washington University, "SEM of some archaeological specimens from Bolivia." 3,000 year old charred seeds and tubers, with a fungus attached to the charred tubers, thought to represent the earliest example of selection for pathogen resistance in the New World.

Justin Zweck, St. Louis University. "SEM of Reproductive Morphology and Pollination Ecology of Pueraria montana (Fabaceae), Kudzu vine." SEM of styles and stigmas revealed stigmatic mechanism for pollination.

Sarah Athie de Souza, Universidade Federal Rural de Pernambuco, Brazil, "SEM analysis of pollen morphology in Stillingia (Euphorbiaceae)." Pollen analysis revealed that previous authors were in error regarding differences between major sections of the genus.

Nallarett Maria Davila, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, Brazil, "SEM of pollen and leaves of Platycarpum (Rubiaceae)."

A graduate level course in Plant Microtechniques at MBG included a 2-week module on SEM techniques. An intensive 2-week graduate level course in Pollination Biology with Peter Kevan from the University of Guelph used SEM on some projects.
